Title: Catering Services for Summer Hospitality Provision at Bournemouth Beach
Description:
The Council has been delivering an Air Festival Hospitality offering since 2018. The purpose of the Air Festival Hospitality is to bring an income stream into the Air Festival and offer a high end hospitality for businesses directly on the flightline further raising the awareness of the event to boost the local economy and to add financially to the event and reputation. The Air Festival Hospitality consists of a covered marquee with a kitchen and decking area in a prime location on the seafront where guests book a ticket for the day to include, food, some drink and entertainment. There is also some private charity and corporate evening functions and a business engagement breakfast meeting.   \r
\r
The catering services for the Air Festival Hospitality is delivered by a third party. It is intended to use Gideon Hitchen to deliver the catering services including all food ordering and menu design for the Summer Hospitality Provision. Gideon Hitchen is responsible for the planning and on site management and delivery of the catering services including the design of the kitchen, ordering and auditing of the food orders, all associated food hygiene, menu design along with the supply of suitably qualified staffing to undertake the catering services. Gideon Hitchen is paid a fixed fee to deliver these services and he will receive a profit share of 10% net should the operation make profit after all the expenditure is taken out.
Supplier [Name|Address|Ref type|Ref Numb: [Gideon Hitchin|14 Lyme St, Axminster EX13 5AU|NONE||Yes|No]

Title: Drink Supplies for Summer Hospitality Provision at Bournemouth Beach
Description:
The Council has been delivering an Air Festival Hospitality offering since 2018. The purpose of the Air Festival Hospitality is to bring an income stream into the Air Festival and offer a high end hospitality for businesses directly on the flightline further raising the awareness of the event to boost the local economy and to add financially to the event and reputation. The Air Festival Hospitality consists of a covered marquee with a kitchen and decking area in a prime location on the seafront where guests book a ticket for the day to include, food, some drink and entertainment. There is also some private charity and corporate evening functions and a business engagement breakfast meeting.   \r
\r
For 2022 the Council is seeking to expand the pop-up catering offer on the beaches and help create a more vibrant environment. As part of this plan there is an opportunity to extend the use of the Air Festival hospitality site into a summer restaurant for a 5-week period. The Air Festival model has worked in previous years for the 4-day event and therefore we will extend the usage to 5 weeks which maximises the site and fixed costs.

Title: Transaction Risking Uplifted Analytics Service Transition
Description:
DWP Digital manages a number of Analytics platforms on premise and in cloud (AWS/Azure) that are utilised by teams including IRIS, Ops Analytics, Cyber Security and individual Digital service design teams. A lot has been learnt from their usage, but more is needed to build on this investment and scale to support the demand, standardised ways of working and the security profile. This is backed up by Analytics being recognised as one of the common reusable services in Digital's Enterprise Architecture. 
Post-Covid the user demands for these platforms significantly increased primarily in response to the Fraud and Error responses as well as operational performance. This has resulted in a need for more data quicker, increased cloud elasticity for greater response times, support for a greater number of users with a lower barrier of entry, increased collaboration between teams and the flexibility to innovate with new tools. 
A partner was brought in to develop this service and accelerate our cloud adoption as DWP did not have enough capacity or skills in order to complete the work itself. Kainos were awarded the contract and have built a series of MVPs deployed to production and have provided that live running service. 
This is a new G-Cloud contract for Kainos to perform an accelerated handover to DWP personnel now that DWP have increased internal resource capacity in the Software Engineering, Platform Engineering and Data Engineering capabilities.
Supplier [Name|Address|Ref type|Ref Numb: [Kainos|4-6 Upper Crescent Belfast BT7 1NT|COMPANIES_HOUSE|NI019370|Yes|No]

Notice Identifier: Midsomer Norton Town Hall Phase 1 Regeneration - Principal Contractor
Title: Midsomer Norton Town Hall Phase 1 Regeneration - Principal Contractor
Description: Grade II listed Midsomer Norton Town Hall will be the subject of a phased programme of work to restore the historic market hall to its original appearance, improve accessibility to the building as a whole through providing increased level access and circulation, and improve facilities such that it can continue to act as civic and community hub of Midsomer Norton. The work will be phased with Phase 1 (the subject of this notice) focusing on the ground floor Market Hall. The works are subject to the conditions of both the planning consent (21/00914/FUL) and listed building consent (21/00915/LBA). It is anticipated that the contract will be the Joint Contractors Tribunal (JCT) Intermediate. Full details of evaluation criteria and how to apply are shown in the document General Information supplied; however this is summarised as follows: tenders will be evaluated on the basis of 70% cost, 30% quality, Quality is broken down as follows: 5% Approach to Health & Safety; 5% Ability to working flexibly on a live site; 5% Programme; 5% Climate Emergency (see Section 4, Supplier Questionnaire); 10% Experience of similar projects on listed buildings including technical competence of direct labour and subcontractors, and a minimum of three case studies. There is a short supplier questionnaire which must be completed as part of the tender submission. All enquiries/ requests for site visits should be directed to Nicola Dyer, Project Manager - nicola.dyer@greenwoodprojects.com. Please note that all submissions should be addressed to the Town Clerk, townclerk@midsomernortontowncouncil.co.uk.

Title: CON-21-141 Cryptoasset Blockchain Analysis Platform
Description:
On 10th January 2020 the FCA became the anti-money laundering and counter terrorist financing (AML/CTF) supervisor for firms carrying out certain in scope cryptoasset activity in the UK. The FCA is required under The Money Laundering, Terrorist Financing and Transfer of Funds (Information on the Payer) Regulations 2017 (MLRs) to approve and register firms conducting in scope cryptoasset activities and ensure that these firms are effectively monitored to secure compliance with these regulations.  
    As the supervisor of in scope cryptoasset activity in the UK, the FCA requires access to specialist services to support the analysis of cryptoasset blockchain data. The FCA is seeking the services of a third-party firm specializing in this area who can provide access to a platform that can support the robust and efficient analysis of cryptoasset blockchain data and provide training and ongoing support in the use of this platform.

Title: RFQ - Expert Handheld XRF Analyser
Description:
The National Physical Laboratory [NPL] requirement is for the provision of an XRF capability, complete with Consumer Goods package (containing RoHS metal and plastic sample sets). The solution shall also provide full alloy material traceability, and a solder calibration set. The purpose is to improve our goods inwards, and regulatory compliance activities across our science and engineering projects, whilst maintain strict adherence to the necessary regulatory compliance directives and standards.

The setup needs to be handheld and portable and able to work within a range of engineering environments without a degrade in performance. There must be fail safes in place if the equipment goes out of spec and it is vital we have traceability.

The instrument must enable the investigation of RoHS compliance within a range of items, ranging from solder on a PCB, through to traceability of materials within a scientific experiment or conducting goods inwards inspection.

Title: Solar Canopy Site Surveys (9), Kingston upon Hull
Description: As part of its commitment to become carbon neutral by 2030, the Authority is keen to promote the use of renewable energy and low carbon technologies within the city.  The installation of generation assets and energy storage will contribute to the city's decarbonisation ambition and will increase renewable energy generation, decrease reliance on power from centralised production, increase local energy security and resilience and provide the Authority with a long-term low carbon revenue source. This project will form part of a wider scheme of energy decarbonisation within the City and is a key element of the City Plan ,  and 2030 Carbon Neutral Strategy.  The Authority has appointed Utility Mapping Group UK Ltd to undertake site surveys relevant to the installation of solar canopy systems upon surface car parks, and at other sites. The Authority has identified 9 sites to be surveyed for this Solar Canopy Site Survey commission, all of which are located in the Kingston upon Hull area.

Title: PharmOutcomes Multi Service Licence
Description:
The County Durham & Darlington Local Pharmaceutical Committee (LPC) provides the council's Public Health team with a multi service sub-licence for the PharmOutcomes system, which is used by the Public Health Pharmacy Advisor and by pharmacies within County Durham who submit claims for local pharmaceutical services to Public Health and are paid via PharmOutcomes.

The LPC has in place an agreement with Pinnacle Health Partnership, the provider of PharmOutcomes, and supplies the sub-licence to Durham County Council at a reduced cost.  The cost for the period 1 July 2021 to 30 June 2022 was £8,028.  The LPC is still currently awaiting confirmation from Pinnacle of the cost of their licence for July 2022 to June 2023 so are unable to confirm the sub-licence cost but have advised that it will be very similar to the current fee but may have a small percentage increase.

The request is therefore for a single supplier negotiation with the LPC to extend the arrangement to 30 June 2023.

Title: CON-21-141 Cryptoasset Blockchain Analysis Platform
Description:
On 10th January 2020 the FCA became the anti-money laundering and counter terrorist financing (AML/CTF) supervisor for firms carrying out certain in scope cryptoasset activity in the UK. The FCA is required under The Money Laundering, Terrorist Financing and Transfer of Funds (Information on the Payer) Regulations 2017 (MLRs) to approve and register firms conducting in scope cryptoasset activities and ensure that these firms are effectively monitored to secure compliance with these regulations.  
    As the supervisor of in scope cryptoasset activity in the UK, the FCA requires access to specialist services to support the analysis of cryptoasset blockchain data. The FCA is seeking the services of a third-party firm specializing in this area who can provide access to a platform that can support the robust and efficient analysis of cryptoasset blockchain data and provide training and ongoing support in the use of this platform.

Title: Adult and Community Learning Framework
Description:
The recently published Working in Hackney Scrutiny Commission Review into the Future World of Work and Skills in Hackney contains three headline recommendations relating to Skills Devolution and Adult Learning:
The Commission recommends that the Council looks at developing measurable outcomes for the journey of residents going through Adult Learning, the Hackney Works programme and the Council's apprenticeship scheme and reports back on the measurements put in place.
The Commission would like the Council to explore the possibility of better aligning the adult community learning provision to its employment support service to provide a seamless service covering learning, training and employment support.
The Commission suggests the Council's employment and skills service adopts an employability skills framework that supports people in and out of work to prepare and develop transferable skills for future job roles.

Title: EM DevCo - Legal Support Services
Description:
Further Competition via CCS framework - WPS Legal Services RM3788
East Midlands Development Corporation (EM DevCo) programme is a ground-breaking initiative that will bring transformational development and infrastructure to an entire region. It emerged out of the East Midlands HS2 Growth Strategy published in September 2017 as a delivery vehicle to maximise the benefits for scalable development and infrastructure investment for the East Midlands region. EM DevCo is a company limited by guarantee owned by 5 member local authorities including Nottinghamshire County Council (host); Leicestershire County Council, Broxtowe Borough Council, Rushcliffe Borough Council and North West Leicestershire District Council.
As an interim vehicle, EM DevCo was established and anticipated to exist in its current state, until any successor statutory development corporation is brought into effect, and this was anticipated to take up to three years at company's inception in 2021. The services outlined in this scope of works will be procured for the duration of the life of the company as a call-off arrangement with appropriate review points and notice periods to be subject to contract.
As EM DevCo enters its second year with the benefit of additional resources from the UK Government, the company needs to appoint a legal team for the duration of the interim vehicle prior to the establishment of the statutory development corporation ("EMDC") to support in four key areas.
Supplier [Name|Address|Ref type|Ref Numb: [Womble Bond Dickinson (UK) LLP|4 More London Riverside, London, SE1 1AU|NONE||No|No]

Title: Supply Chain Specialist procurement opportunity
Description:
TSCN is currently looking to procure an individual / organisation to identify and work with businesses within the more developed area of our region concentrating on the York area of the York, North Yorkshire LEP (as shown in Appendix 4 covering York, Selby, Harrogate and Craven) by offering direct business support on a one to one basis to help them increase their customer base and maximise opportunities to quote for and/or apply for relevant tenders. 

As a representative of The Supply Chain Network the work will involve:
•	Identifying businesses for support within the designated region and working with the TSCN team to confirm eligibility
•	Responding to direct referrals from the TSCN team for businesses with specific supply chain requirements
•	Directly working with said businesses to ensure clear understanding of individual business needs to win more customers/work and enable effective action plans to be developed
•	Continuing to directly work with businesses to help them meet identified needs
•	Communicating continually ensuring clear discussions and actions are recorded in agreement with the company/project
•	Continually liaising with TSCN team to feed in the requirements and for ongoing additional support for the company
•	Capturing all actions and meetings onto the TSCN paperwork to the required standards
•	Providing ongoing business intelligence to TSCN as themes and information is identified
•	Liaising, supporting and working with project team advisers as required
Contracted Targets:
•	Identifying a minimum of 40 new businesses for enrolment onto the programme with identification of specific needs/requirements as above
•	Working directly with a minimum of 20 businesses on a programme of one to one support offering direct supply chain knowledge and expertise
•	Contributing to the projects outputs by identifying outcomes of the support offered through jobs and/or new products/services created
•	The contract awarded is envisaged to be for 9 months in line with the TSCN project end date

Milestones
1.	Tender advertised	Monday 23rd May 2022
2.	Final submission of queries and questions regarding tender	Noon Wednesday 1st June 2022
3.	Closing date for submissions	Noon Monday 6th June 2022
4.	Scoring of submissions 	w/c 6th June 2022
5.	Notification to successful applicants	Monday 13th June 2022
6.	Inception meetings and agreement of approach	June 2022
7.	Delivery of contract	Between July 2022 - April 2023

Questions about the specification should be directed to Josh Elliott-Shircore via email Josh.shircore@eastriding.gov.uk by Noon Wednesday the 1st June 2022 
If you are interested in this opportunity responses should be sent to Josh Elliot-Shircore via email Josh.shircore@eastriding.gov.uk by Noon Monday the 6th June 2022

Title: National Digital Support Evaluation Contract
Description:
The HMCTS user base is a varied one, and there is a need to support a potentially significant number of users who cannot or will not go online by themselves. The Programme has offered various forms of support, including telephone assistance and face to face assistance, to help these users interact with services in the preferred digital channels. The term for this type of support is Digital Support (DS), and this principle underpins the HMCTS vision of a justice system that is accessible to all. 
An important aspect of this new service is to undertake a process evaluation which will seek to understand how well the National Digital Support Service and its processes are working for both the users in receipt of support and the organisation providing the support. This will inform decisions for the continuation, and improvement, of the National Digital Support Services.

Title: ICT Project Delivery Partner
Description: The Harris Federation (HF) is a Federation of 51 Academies, which are currently located in the London area with the Federation Head Office in East Croydon.The Federation Website is https://www.harrisfederation.org.ukThe ICT Support and delivery of upgrades/projects at the Federation is currently all delivered 'in house' with occasional ad-hoc contractor support.The Federation benefits from a degree of standardisation in its ICT solution, but at the same time is also cognisant that ICT solutions and technology are developing rapidly.There is currently a need to refresh a significant amount of aged equipment across the Federation as part of an ongoing refresh programme over a number of years. Therefore, to enable the Federation's IT team to focus on the management of ICT and not need to be concerned with the increasing challenges regarding ICT supply, procurement, implementation and resourcing the decision has been taken to identify an ICT Implementation Partner. At a high level, the Partner will be responsible for supply of equipment and implementation through ongoing multiple projects so that over the lifetime of the contract all Federation schools will have been refreshed. The Federation IT team will continue to maintain and support the ICT.To give an indication of the equipment and tasks the partner would need to deliver are as follows:- All hardware supply- Maintenance agreements- Relevant licencing- A move to serverless schools where relevant- Cabling- CCTV systems- All installation services- Programme Management- Project Management- Management of ad-hoc purchases- Pre-Testing against a Standard Network Design (SND)- Formal testing against SND- Functional testing with schools- User Training - School staff- Handover Training - School technical staff- Asset tagging of all installed equipment- Asset register management for both hardware & software- Escalated Support for 6 months (inc SLA to measure performance) following each school deployment- Equipment disposal / re-cycling- Due Diligence services for both existing & new schools- Commitments to support innovation- Budget risk post Order- Innovation & ongoing input into SND- Collective partnership (CSR) targets aligned to the Federation objectives

Title: Evaluation of the Research & Statistics Fund for the BFI - AWARD
Description:
The British Film Institute (the "BFI") has a dedicated National Lottery-funded Research & Statistics Fund (the "Fund"). The Fund has been operational since 2015 and has an external advisory group that meets three times a year to advise on data purchases and research priorities.
      
      A number of ground-breaking studies have been commissioned through the Fund over the past seven years, including: Workforce Diversity Evidence Review; Screen Business (2018 and 2021 editions); A Screen New Deal, Horizon Scan (title TBC); Film in the Wider World (not yet published); and The Impacts of Leaving the EU on the UK's Screen Sector. Other notable outputs include the annual BFI Statistical Yearbook and Official Statistics releases and its well-received 'Insight Exchange' events. There is also an enquiry service whereby data purchased through the Fund is used to respond to queries and data requests from industry, the international screen sector, the press, academics, students and the public.
      
      The BFI wishes to commission an evaluation which will assess the overall impacts of the Research & Statistics Fund, including how it contributes and adds value to the UK screen sector ecosystem.
      
      The evaluation should also examine whether the current aims, objectives and primary delivery methods of the Fund are still fit for purpose. We would like to understand whether our funding is being targeted in the right areas, whether we need to broaden our scope and where we should focus our investment in the future.
      
      The approach should cover both impact and process evaluation.
      
      Full details are set out in the ITT.
      
      The closing date for this tender is 12:00 noon on 8 June 2022.

Title: The Supply of CRM Software and Configuration Services to Support the  Transformation of Student Acquisition
Description:
The University of Birmingham invites tenders for supply of Customer Relationship Management (CRM) software and associated configuration services to support the transformation of the student acquisition process and experience.
The solution will replace several tools and technology used to support student attraction, application, and conversion activities across the entire education portfolio.
At the heart of our ambition lies a desire to take full advantage of the latest marketing and process automation opportunities available within a modern CRM solution while also providing our staff and prospective students an efficient and effective user experience.
Key areas of activity included within the scope of requirements include marketing, campaigns, events, stakeholder engagement, enquiry management, application processing and admissions.
It is envisaged that the University will create an internal product team to work alongside the successful supplier to rollout and continually iterate upon an initial configuration of a solution that has the potential to become an institution wide CRM platform.
We would therefore welcome the opportunity for potential suppliers to engage with us to refine these requirements through competitive dialogue.

Title: Manufacture and Supply of Custom Battery Packs
Description:
The Metropolitan Police Service (MPS) wishes to purchase 60 off custom battery packs built and supplied to the following specification:
      
      Packs to be constructed of 24 x Saft LS14500 3.6v 2.6Ah cells configured in a 2 x 12 flat configuration in parallel to provide a 3.6v 62.4Ah battery. All cells to have a Schottky diode between them to prevent against reverse current between cells and a 500mA slow blow fuse is to be fitted on the output of the pack. Output connections to be 150mm red/black flying leads. Unfortunately there is no technical drawing available but a word document with photographs of an opened existing solution is attached for visual clarification. 
       Electronic quotations must be emailed back to David.Addley@met.police.uk no later than 30/06/2022
      
      All materials required for the manufacturing process must be available or readily sourced with no disparate lead times other than those required for the manufacturing process.
      
      The quotations should include all the points detailed in this request for quotation.
      
      Please note that quotes provided must be fully inclusive outlining costs such as delivery.   
       The Metropolitan Police Service is famed around the world and has a unique place in the history of policing. It is by far the largest of the police services that operate in the UK. The Royal Parks Constabulary has now become part of the MPS.
      
      Today, the MPS employs approximately 31,141 officers, 13,661 police staff, 414 traffic wardens and 2,106 Police Community Support Officers (PCSOs), and, since the realignment of police boundaries in April 2000, it covers an area of 620 square miles and a population of 7.2million.
      
      Staff of the MPS (other than police officers) are employed by the MOPAC (Mayor's Office for Policing and Crime) but the power to appoint and dismiss them vests in the Commissioner. The MPS covers the area broadly within the boundaries of the M25. Day-to-day policing is the responsibility of 32 Borough Operational Command Units supported by centralised specialist policing units and other management, admin and support functions. 
       The standard terms and conditions have been attached for your information, if you are unable to comply with our terms and conditions please do not bid for this contract.  MPS standards terms will not be amended for contracts less than £50,000 in value.
Contact Address 1: DO NOT AMEND - Empress State Building
Additional Text: The standard terms and conditions have been attached for your information, if you are unable to comply with our terms and conditions please do not bid for this contract.  MPS standards terms will not be amended for contracts less than £50,000 in value.

Organisation Name: North West London Clinical Commissioning Group
Title: Urgent Treatment Centres
Description:
To ensure continuity of the service, a short term contract from 1st April 2022 to 31st January 2023 (10 months) has been awarded to Greenbrook Healthcare whilst undergoing a procurement exercise for the service. Market Engagement has been undertaken in advance.

The procurement is currently underway, FTS Notice reference: 2022/S 000-013667.

The UTCs are located at Ealing Hospital, Northwick Park,
Central Middlesex Hospital and Hillingdon Hospital sites.

The core set of standards for urgent treatment centres (UTC)
are:

a. To be able to access urgent treatment centres that are,
GP-led, staffed by GPs, nurses and other clinicians, with
access to simple diagnostics, e.g. urinalysis, ECG and in
some cases X-ray.

b. Have a consistent route to access urgent appointments
offered within 4hrs and booked through NHS 111, ambulance
services and general practice. A walk-in access option will be
available.

c. Increasingly be able to access routine and same-day
appointments, and out-of-hours general practice, for both
urgent and routine appointments, at the same facility, where
geographically appropriate.

d. Know that the urgent treatment centre is part of locally
integrated urgent and emergency care services working in
conjunction with the ambulance service, NHS 111, local GPs,
hospital A&E services and other local providers.
The impact will be reduced attendance at, and conveyance
to, A& E as a result of this standardisation and simplified
access, as well as improved patient convenience.

Description:
To ensure continuity of the service, a short term contract from 1st April 2022 to 31st January 2023 (10 months) has been awarded to Vocare Ltd whilst undergoing a procurement exercise for the service. Market Engagement has been undertaken in advance.

The procurement is currently underway, FTS Notice reference: 2022/S 000-013667.

The UTC is located at St Mary's Hospital.

The core set of standards for urgent treatment centres (UTC)
are:

a. To be able to access urgent treatment centres that are GP-
led, staffed by GPs, nurses and other clinicians, with access
to simple diagnostics, e.g. urinalysis, ECG and in some
cases X-ray.

b. Have a consistent route to access urgent appointments offered within 4hrs and booked through NHS 111, ambulance
services and general practice. A walk-in access option will be
available.

c. Increasingly be able to access routine and same-day
appointments, and out-of-hours general practice, for both
urgent and routine appointments, at the same facility, where
geographically appropriate.

d. Know that the urgent treatment centre is part of locally
integrated urgent and emergency care services working in
conjunction with the ambulance service, NHS111, local GPs,
hospital A&E services and other local providers.
The impact will be reduced attendance at, and conveyance
to, A&E as a result of this standardisation and simplified
access, as well as improved patient convenience.

Title: PROVISION OF SEMLEP BUILDING BETTER OPPORTUNITIES - SUPPORTING EMPLOYMENT
Description:
1.1.	Luton Borough Council is looking to engage qualified organisations to quote for the provision of SEMLEP BUILDING BETTER OPPORTUNTIES - SUPPORTING EMPLOYMENT
Luton Council is the Lead Accountable Body for the SEMLEP (South East Midlands Local Enterprise Partnership) BBO project which is funded by the European Social Fund and The National Lottery Community Fund. The project has been running across the SEMLEP region since 2016. The project aims to support more than 2300 unemployed and economically inactive people to overcome barriers to employment in the whole of the SEMLEP area including: Bedford, Central Bedfordshire, Luton, Milton Keynes and Northamptonshire. We would like to bring some new partners into the programme in order to help support more SEMLEP residents.  The project aims to tackle worklessness to raise the aspirations of people and communities, and to support participants to overcome barriers, increase confidence and move into, or nearer to, paid employment (depending on their starting point)

Title: PRICE (Protecting Rights In a Caring Environment) "Train the Trainers" Programme
Description:
PRICE (Protecting Rights in a Caring Environment) is the model of behaviour management training used within Aycliffe Secure Centre. 

The programme places a significant focus upon preventative strategies as well as the de-escalation and defusing elements of supporting behaviour whilst recognising it is sometimes necessary to use physical intervention to hold a service user to protect their wellbeing and the welfare of others. The model offers staff a 'toolbox' of skills and strategies to better deal with the everyday occurring situations that can escalate and develop into conflict, without compromising the ultimate welfare and safety of the service user or staff member.

Aycliffe Secure Centre was involved in the development of PRICE, responding to concerns about the safety and welfare of looked after children and young people, in relation to how their behaviour was being physically managed in residential establishments. The Service has been using the system for over 20 years. 

A "train the trainer" model is used by PRICE. Trainers within Durham County Council who are competent and capable users of PRICE techniques are trained and provided with annual refresher training by PRICE so they can train others. 

This contract should allow for both initial and refresher "train the trainer" courses as required over the period.

Title: T0334 Delay from Roadwork Metric- Development Stage
Description: We are seeking technical support for this work to build on feasibility stage analysis previously undertaken to develop a metric for the Development Stage which is appropriate for National Highways. It was recommended in Feasibility that two options are taken forward for further development. These options are 'individual user delay' and 'delay index'. Both options will make enhancements to the current delay from roadworks performance indicator to include delays on diversion routes and delays experienced by customers upstream to or in close proximity to roadworks. It is essential that the metric can be influenced by operational levers of National Highways in order to improve performance. The metric and any potential targets must also be achievable by National Highways within the RIS period. The metric development stage needs to address how to handle delays caused by incidents within roadworks. The metric needs to be developed using a method that National Highways can take on and productionise.
Attachments: T0334  SPaTS 2 Award Letter - Arup - trans.docx

Title: Pearces Mill Re-roofing Works
Description:
The Pearce's Mill Building is a three-storey roughcast rendered masonry structure with a hipped roof of profiled cement board. The majority of the ground floor area is raised approx. 900mm above finished wharf level, with a small loading bay area to the east elevation. The building has two existing staircases serving both upper floor levels. One exits to the north and one to the south-east corner. Both are within existing masonry cores. This building is currently used as a joinery workshop at ground floor level and small artist studios and offices at the upper levels - total floor area of approx. 995m2.

The works will be phased to allow continued use of the ground floor and first-floor space. The upper level (2nd floor) is essentially one open plan space open to the roof void. The building itself is located on a busy working wharf which will require careful consideration in the planning of the works.

KML wishes to appoint a contractor to carry out the re-roofing work package on a supply & fit basis. Whilst there is a specification for these works, we welcome any suggestions with regards to more efficient solutions.

Title: NCC807 Support for Young Carers in Northumberland
Description:
A young carer is defined as "anyone under the age of 18 whose life is in some way restricted because of the need to take responsibility for the care of someone, usually in their family". Under the legislation is called the Children and Families Act 2014 and the Care Act 2014 Local Authorities must assess whether young carers have support needs and take 'reasonable steps' to identify and try to provide for those support needs. 

The level of care is defined as providing regular and ongoing care and emotional support to a family member who is physically or mentally ill, disabled or misuses substances. The range and scale of caring varies greatly. It can involve lots of physical care including personal care, giving medication, and helping someone to dress or move around. It can be looking after siblings, paying bills, cooking, cleaning, shopping, or translating.  Some young carers give no physical care but provide emotional support, particularly for someone who has a mental health condition or misuses substances.

The Council wish to commission a Provider to process referrals from its 'front door' using its young carer assessment process and toolkit and identify appropriate support for individual young carers in Northumberland. Further details of the Contracting Authority's requirements under the Contract and other relevant information are detailed in the Specification at Schedule 2.

Title: SQM Services from 1 October 2022
Description:
The Legal Aid Agency ("LAA") invited Applicants to tender for a concession contract ("Contract") to administer the LAA's Specialist Quality Mark ("SQM"), from 1 October 2022.

The SQM is the LAA's organisational quality standard designed to ensure that Legal Services Providers are well run and provide good client care. The SQM gives assurance regarding the quality of advice in several ways which, whilst not direct measures of quality are fundamental to reliable delivery of a quality service and therefore are fundamentally important to the delivery of legal aid services. Compliance with the SQM, or equivalent standard (e.g. Lexcel), is a requirement for Legal Services Providers that have, or are seeking to have, a contract with the LAA.

The LAA intends to enter into contract with one (1) organisation to administer the LAA's SQM under a licence. On the LAA's behalf, the Licensee will provide the SQM Services, which include auditing and assessing Legal Services Providers that apply for SQM accreditation.

This notice confirms the outcome of that procurement.

Title: Exploring an Independent Sector Partnership for NHS Community Diagnostic Centres
Description:
In the South West, there is a strong drive to reduce waiting times for diagnostics and to accelerate the delivery of CDCs through a combination of NHS and private sector resources.
• Whilst the service model is clearly defined in the report, further work is needed to develop the detailed service requirements linked to local services, define the workforce and financial model and prepare for an open procurement process, drawing on expert commercial and legal advice.
• The regional diagnostics team is working with the seven local systems in the South West and with the national teams involved in diagnostics, people development, workforce planning, finance, commercial and legal issues to develop the specific local requirements for the delivery of CDCs. The South West will be able to benefit from the learning of other CDCs in place - and also contribute to the learning elsewhere through its accelerated plans for delivery at scale.
• In addition to the NHS resources available for the delivery of CDCs, the South West region wishes to secure consultancy assistance, in particular to support the design of the commercial model and the procurement of certain diagnostic services from private sector partners.
Supplier [Name|Address|Ref type|Ref Numb: [Akeso & Company Limited|11 Curistor Street, London, EC4A 1LL|NONE||No|No]

Title: T0305 TETI0050 ADAS user attentiveness rapid evidence assessment
Description:
New Advanced Driver Assistance Systems (ADAS) features are being developed that reduce the burden on the driver to perform the driving task. These features can control steering, braking and acceleration, however, the users must still remain attentive as they continue to be responsible for the vehicle. 
The objective of the Department for Transport is to gain insight and evidence to support the further development of regulations governing ADAS features. Ensuring that they achieve their principle objective of reducing collisions and that they don't result in reduced driver attentiveness or misuse, to the detriment of the vehicle occupants and other road users.
 
Consequently, the Department is seeking a rapid evidence assessment of user attentiveness when using ADAS to determine if users are losing attentiveness and in the event they are, determine the causes. Additionally, if the driver attentiveness is lost, how can it be quickly and safely regained?
Attachments: T0305 TETI0050 SPaTS 2 DfT Award Letter - Arup - trans.docx

Title: Roots in Time Archaeology  - Community Excavation - AWARD
Description:
Worcestershire County Council has successfully obtained  funding from the National Lottery Heritage Fund for Roots in Time (RiT) - A project to explore the heritage of a new public open space and woodland at Norton, Evesham. 
       A key part of the project is a community excavation to be held in late summer of 2022.  The Council are looking for a contractor to deliver the excavation and post-excavation work, involving local people and groups.
      The archaeological project must be carried out in line with the Chartered Institute for Archaeologists Standard and Guidance for Archaeological Excavations.
      The works as set out in the specification will be a programme of hands-on archaeological investigations, events engaging local communities will run for 18 months, with onsite activities primarily taking place in late summer 2022 followed by a winter of post-excavation analysis with community involvement. 
      
      Weighting - Cost 60%  - Quality 30% - Social Value - 10%
      It is on this basis that we invite suitable contractors to provide a full turn-key project compliant quotation, to deliver this project within set time scales.
      All tender documents must be uploaded to the portal by the due date as late returns will not be accepted.
      
      To register your interest or to download all tender documents please visit the Worcestershire County Council's e-procurement portal at: www.in-tendhost.co.uk/worcestershire
      Tenders and supporting documents shall be in English and any contract subsequently entered in to shall be subject to English Law
      .
      Please note that the Supplier is responsible for obtaining all information necessary for the preparation of the tender submission. All cost, expenses and liabilities incurred by the Supplier in connection with the preparation of their submission, the Form of Tender and Pricing Schedule shall be borne by the Supplier.
      Please see tender documents and submit your return and associated documents by the due date.
      
      Worcestershire County Council reserve the right not to award a contract in full or in part.
      
      Form of Contract: NEC3 -  Engineering and Construction Short Contract (ECSC) appended with an Archaeological  Project Design (PD) or Written Scheme of  Investigation (WSI)

Title: Blackpool Advocacy Hub 2022
Description: Blackpool Council seeks to appoint one provider of Advocacy services under a single contract which will cover all Advocacy provision in Blackpool. This will bring Advocacy services for adults and children together under a single contract to create a "Single Point of Access" to Advocacy Services through the "Blackpool Advocacy Hub". The aim is for a coordinated and joined up Advocacy Service to deliver all Independent Advocacy for eligible adults, children and young people with health and social care needs (comprising adults with learning difficulties, mental health problems, physical and sensory, autistic spectrum conditions and older people, looked after children) living in Blackpool.

Title: Targeted Relationships
Description:
Kent County Council's requirement for an organisation to deliver a Targeted Relationships and Sex Education (RSE) and Emotional Resilience Intervention to children and young people in Kent aged 10-18 years each year. 

We want to improve outcomes for children and young people aged 10-18 years who have experienced trauma such as sexual exploitation, coercive and abusive relationships, and familial domestic abuse. These children and young people are at immediate risk of poor outcomes and, unless their needs are addressed, will continue to experience the impact of these traumas throughout their lives.

The service will work in partnership with the wider system of support, care and protection
being provided to the child or young person, their siblings and their family, thus complementing the
work of early help and prevention, specialist children's services, counselling services and specialist mental health services.

Title: ORT_0044  Provision of HADECS Enforcement Technical Support Services
Description:
The purpose of this contract award notice is to publish information in relation to the award of the  ORT_0044 Provision of HADECS Enforcement Technical Support Call-off Contract, in accordance with Regulation 112 of the Public Contract Regulations 2015 (as amended).

The Call-Off Contract has been awarded under Lot 5 of the Operational Technology Commercial Framework. 

The Call-Off Contract has an initial duration of two years, followed by extension options of up to two years in total. The award value is £1.262m for the first two years, but up to £2.6m in total, if the optional extension options are exercised. Hence the award value for the purposes of this contract award notice is set at £2.6m

National Highways installs, develops, operates and maintains a Home Office Type 
Approved (HOTA) speed enforcement service known as HADECS (derived from Highways Agency Digital Enforcement and Compliance System). The HADECS service provides smart motorways with the essential speed enforcement capability which encourages customers to adhere to the variable mandatory speed limits enabling smart motorways to deliver its safety and journey time benefits.  

The objective of the HADECS Enforcement Technical Support Call-Off Contract is to provide a technical services team with experience and knowledge of Type Approved camera enforcement and compliance systems to support and assure the development, delivery, operation and maintenance of the HADECS enforcement cameras system service delivered by National Highways' HADECS service providers.  
 
This provides critical assurance to National Highways that National Highways HADECS systems are safe, fit for purpose and have been supplied, installed, operated and maintained to the HOTA regulations. 
 
This enables National Highways and Police authorities to use these systems to realise the benefits of smart motorways. 
 
The  Call-Off Contract also includes for the provisioning of technical project delivery support to complete the retender of the current HADECS contract. This will involve supporting National Highways with completion of business case(s), compilation of the technical specifications and support in assessing tender submissions.
Contact Address 1: National Highways Limited, Temple Quay House, 2 The Square,  Temple Quay, Bristol

Title: NUN - Local Plan Review (Air Quality, Heritage and Landscape Assessments) - AWARD
Description:
Provision of three reports to inform the local borough plan review. 
      
      Lot 1 - Air Quality Assessment
      This piece of work is for the Planning Policy team as part of the Borough Plan Review. This project is to provide an update to the previous air quality assessment evidence base carried out for the previous Borough Plan (2019). The updates are required due to the undertaking of the Borough Plan review to ensure the evidence base uses the latest and projected figures and is in line with latest legislation to assess the effects of the proposed housing and employment allocations that are to be brought forwards as part of the Review. The proposal is to assess the individual sites but also the cumulative impact to the Boroughs two   Air Quality Management Areas (AQMA) as well as the impact to Coventry City Councils city wide AQMA.
      
      Lot 2 - Heritage Assessment 
      This piece of work is for the Planning Policy team as part of the Borough Plan Review. This project is to provide an update to the previous heritage assessment evidence base for the previous Borough Plan (2019). The updates to the evidence base is for the residential and employment sites that are proposed to make up the strategic sites for the new plan period up to 2039. These sites consist of either new sites that have come forwards under the call for sites or the existing sites carried forwards from the previous plan period. 
      
      This work is to ensure the historic environment is conserved and enhanced and ensure that there are positive policies in place for the conservation and enjoyment of the historic environment for both designated and non-designated heritage assets and their settings.  
      
      This assessment should be based on the existing methodology and approach used within the Council's latest Borough Plan Heritage Assessment (2016)  and Historic Environment Assessment (2014). The work should have reference to the National Planning Policy Framework 2021 and other relevant legislation.   
      
      Lot 3 - Landscape Assessment 
      Production of Landscape Assessment Reports to support the production of the Borough Plan Review Development Plan Document.

Title: VEAT Notice for Bus Contingency Provision during the Commonwealth Games
Description:
This is a VEAT Notice, not an opportunity listing.

There is a risk that industrial action on the UK rail network may coincide with the Commonwealth Games, which will be hosted in the West Midlands between 28 July and 9 August. On the busiest days, over 100,000 rail trips, as part of a journey to and from the Games, are predicted.

The transport plan for the Games' venues indicates that approximately 40% of workforce and spectators would be expected to travel to the Games events by train.  A contingency plan is therefore required should the rail network be unavailable, or severely reduced, due to industrial action.

This contingency plan is being developed by the Transport for West Midlands Team of the West Midlands Combined Authority ("WMCA") on behalf of the Commonwealth Games Organising Committee.  A key element of the contingency plan is to provide additional bus services within the West Midlands region, to provide additional shuttle services between venues, city centres and Park & Ride sites.  Another important aspect is the provision of additional coach capacity from towns and cities across the UK, replacing the connections that would otherwise be offered by the rail network.

Market assessment to identify and source additional buses and coaches in order to enact the  contingency plan was undertaken at a time when there were and are many other calls on scarce buses, coaches and drivers, to serve other major events, airports, critical workplaces and provide rail replacement services.  As a result, it was critical  that WMCA secure bus operators in the shortest possible time and obtain the maximum number of resources mobilised and ready for 23rd July 2022.  This will allow for driver route training and mobilisation plus Opening ceremony full dress rehearsals 24th and 26th July.

As a consequence of a UK wide rapid market engagement with regional, national bus and coach operators WMCA has found capacity and capability that achieves the most desirable possible outcome given the current restrictions and direct awards, in accordance with Clause 32(2)(C) of the Public Contracting Regulations 2015, will be made at the end of a 10 day standstill period.

This has enabled WMCA to acquire buses, coaches and drivers in the shortest possible time and maximise the resources available to deliver its contingency plan.
